sn35.76:1.1.eng: The Venerable Rādha went up to the Buddha …

sn35.76:1.2.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā rādho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn35.76:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn35.76:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn35.76:1.4.pli: “Yaṃ kho, rādha, aniccaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.76:1.4.eng: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is impermanent.

sn35.76:1.5.pli: Kiñca, rādha, aniccaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo?
sn35.76:1.5.comm: The following discourses have a brief question at this point, whereas the MS edition repeats the phrase “you should give up desire”. I follow the shorter version, found here in PTS and Bodhi.

sn35.76:1.8.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ. Tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…
sn35.76:1.8.eng: And the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also impermanent. You should give up desire for it.

sn35.76:1.11.pli: mano anicco. Tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.76:1.15.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ. Tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.76:1.15.eng: And the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also impermanent. You should give up desire for it.

sn35.76:1.16.pli: Yaṃ kho, rādha, aniccaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn35.76:1.16.eng: You should give up desire for what is impermanent.”

sn35.77:1.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho, rādha, dukkhaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.77:1.1.eng: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is suffering. …”

sn35.77:1.3.pli: Cakkhu kho, rādha, dukkhaṃ. Tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.77:1.7.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassa …pe… adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ. Tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…

sn35.77:1.12.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ. Tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.77:1.13.pli: Yaṃ kho, rādha, dukkhaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.

sn35.78:1.1.pli: “Yo kho, rādha, anattā tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.78:1.1.eng: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is not-self. …”

sn35.78:1.3.pli: Cakkhu kho, rādha, anattā. Tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.78:1.12.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattā. Tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.78:1.13.pli: Yo kho, rādha, anattā tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.

sn35.79:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn35.79:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha …

sn35.79:1.2.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn35.79:1.3.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?
sn35.79:1.3.eng: “Sir, is there one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”

sn35.79:2.1.pli: “Atthi kho, bhikkhu, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.

sn35.79:3.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?

sn35.79:4.1.pli: “Avijjā kho, bhikkhu, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.
sn35.79:4.1.eng: “Ignorance is one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”
sn35.79:4.1.comm: This emphasizes ignorance as the root defilement. That is not to say, however, that ignorance is unconditioned, as it is conditioned by the five hindrances which obstruct wisdom (AN 10.61).

sn35.79:5.1.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?
sn35.79:5.1.eng: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”

sn35.79:6.1.pli: “Cakkhuṃ kho, bhikkhu, aniccato jānato passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjati. Rūpe … cakkhuviññāṇaṃ … cakkhusamphassaṃ …
sn35.79:6.1.eng: “When a mendicant knows and sees the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.

sn35.79:6.2.pli: yampidaṃ, cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccato jānato passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjati …pe…
sn35.79:6.2.eng: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises. …

sn35.79:6.3.pli: manaṃ aniccato jānato passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjati. Dhamme … manoviññāṇaṃ … manosamphassaṃ …
sn35.79:6.3.eng: Knowing and seeing the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.

sn35.79:6.4.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccato jānato passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjati.
sn35.79:6.4.eng: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.

sn35.79:6.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.
sn35.79:6.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”

sn35.8:0.3.eng: The Interior as Suffering in the Three Times

sn35.8:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the eye of the past and future is suffering,

sn35.8:1.3.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ cakkhusmiṃ anapekkho hoti;
sn35.8:1.3.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple is not concerned with the eye of the past,

sn35.8:1.4.eng: they don’t look forward to enjoying the eye in the future,

sn35.8:1.5.pli: paccuppannassa cakkhussa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.
sn35.8:1.5.eng: and they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye in the present. …”

sn35.8:1.10.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītāya jivhāya anapekkho hoti;

sn35.8:1.12.pli: paccuppannāya jivhāya nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hoti.

sn35.8:1.16.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako atītasmiṃ manasmiṃ anapekkho hoti;

sn35.8:1.18.pli: paccuppannassa manassa nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya paṭipanno hotī”ti.

sn35.80:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn35.80:1.2.pli: “atthi nu kho, bhante, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?
sn35.80:1.2.eng: “Sir, is there one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge?”

sn35.80:2.1.pli: “Atthi kho, bhikkhu, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.

sn35.80:3.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?

sn35.80:4.1.pli: “Avijjā kho, bhikkhu, eko dhammo yassa pahānā bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.
sn35.80:4.1.eng: “Ignorance is one thing such that by giving it up a mendicant gives up ignorance and gives rise to knowledge.”

sn35.80:5.1.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti?
sn35.80:5.1.eng: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”

sn35.80:6.2.comm: “‘Nothing is worth insisting on” (sabbe dhammā nālaṁ abhinivesāyā) occurs several times (see especially MN 37:3.2 and note). “Insistence” (abinivesa) is a name for defilements that have become rigidly stuck, particularly the dogmatic insistence that one is correct and everyone else is wrong.

sn35.80:6.3.eng: When a mendicant has heard that

sn35.80:6.5.pli: So sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbaṃ dhammaṃ parijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ pariññāya sabbanimittāni aññato passati, cakkhuṃ aññato passati, rūpe …
sn35.80:6.5.eng: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Completely understanding all things, they see all signs as other. They see the eye, sights,
sn35.80:6.5.comm: Aññato means “as other”. Like parato (“as alien”), it is a term for not-self. | “All signs” are the features of experience that the mind hooks on to as desirable, as permanent, or as Self.

sn35.80:6.8.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aññato passati …pe…
sn35.80:6.8.eng: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact as other. …

sn35.80:6.12.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aññato passati.
sn35.80:6.12.eng: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact as other.

sn35.80:6.13.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato bhikkhuno avijjā pahīyati, vijjā uppajjatī”ti.
sn35.80:6.13.eng: That’s how a mendicant knows and sees so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”

sn35.81:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn35.81:1.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn35.81:1.2.pli: “idha no, bhante, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā amhe evaṃ pucchanti:
sn35.81:1.2.eng: “Sir, sometimes wanderers of other religions ask us:

sn35.81:1.3.eng: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’

sn35.81:1.4.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā mayaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākaroma:

sn35.81:1.5.pli: ‘dukkhassa kho, āvuso, pariññatthaṃ bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti.
sn35.81:1.5.eng: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.’
sn35.81:1.5.comm: The “complete understanding” of suffering is part of the complex relating to the full realization of the four noble truths, the others being giving up the cause; realizing the cessation; and developing the path. Thus by mentioning “complete understanding”, all four are implied.

sn35.81:1.6.pli: Kacci mayaṃ, bhante, evaṃ puṭṭhā evaṃ byākaramānā vuttavādino ceva bhagavato homa, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhāma, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaroma, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchatī”ti?
sn35.81:1.6.eng: Answering this way, we trust that we repeat what the Buddha has said, and don’t misrepresent him with an untruth. We trust our explanation is in line with the teaching, and that there are no legitimate grounds for rebuttal or criticism.”

sn35.81:2.1.pli: “Taggha tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ puṭṭhā evaṃ byākaramānā vuttavādino ceva me hotha, na ca maṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhatha, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākarotha, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgacchati.
sn35.81:2.1.eng: “Indeed, in answering this way you repeat what I’ve said, and don’t misrepresent me with an untruth. Your explanation is in line with the teaching, and there are no legitimate grounds for rebuttal or criticism.

sn35.81:2.2.pli: Dukkhassa hi, bhikkhave, pariññatthaṃ mayi brahmacariyaṃ vussati.
sn35.81:2.2.eng: For the purpose of leading the spiritual life under me is to completely understand suffering.

sn35.81:2.3.pli: Sace pana vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn35.81:2.3.eng: If wanderers of other religions were to ask you:

sn35.81:2.4.pli: ‘katamaṃ pana taṃ, āvuso, dukkhaṃ, yassa pariññāya samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti?

sn35.81:2.5.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:

sn35.81:2.6.pli: ‘cakkhu kho, āvuso, dukkhaṃ, tassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati.
sn35.81:2.6.eng: ‘Reverends, the eye is suffering. The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.

sn35.81:2.8.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ.
sn35.81:2.8.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also suffering.

sn35.81:2.9.eng: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.

sn35.81:2.11.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ.
sn35.81:2.11.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also suffering.

sn35.81:2.12.eng: The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.

sn35.81:2.13.pli: Idaṃ kho taṃ, āvuso, dukkhaṃ, tassa pariññāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti.
sn35.81:2.13.eng: This is that suffering. The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.’

sn35.81:2.14.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyāthā”ti.
sn35.81:2.14.eng: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”

sn35.82:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.82:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and said to him:

sn35.82:2.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the world’.

sn35.82:2.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, lokoti vuccatī”ti?

sn35.82:2.3.eng: “It wears away, mendicant, that’s why it’s called ‘the world’.
sn35.82:2.3.comm: The Pali puns lujjati (“wear away”) with loka (“world”). Normally lujjati is “fall apart, disintegrate” (see SN 22.93), but where it puns with “world” (here and SN 35.84) I translate as “wear away”, which is justified by the use at AN 3.132:1.7. This pun might seem obvious to “world-weary” folks of today, but it is the deliberate opposite of loka’s underlying sense. It originally referred to “light”, especially the bright lights of the heavens, hence “cosmos” and “world” generally. See note on MN 7:19.6 for details.

sn35.82:2.6.pli: Rūpā lujjanti, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ lujjati, cakkhusamphasso lujjati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi lujjati …pe…
sn35.82:2.6.eng: Sights … eye consciousness … eye contact is wearing away. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also wearing away.

sn35.82:2.8.pli: mano lujjati, dhammā lujjanti, manoviññāṇaṃ lujjati, manosamphasso lujjati, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi lujjati.
sn35.82:2.8.eng: The mind … ideas … mind consciousness … mind contact is wearing away. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also wearing away.

sn35.82:2.9.pli: Lujjatīti kho, bhikkhu, tasmā lokoti vuccatī”ti.
sn35.82:2.9.eng: It wears away, mendicant, that’s why it’s called ‘the world’.”

sn35.83:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā phagguno …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā phagguno bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.83:1.1.eng: And then Venerable Phagguna went up to the Buddha … and said to him:

sn35.83:2.1.pli: “Atthi nu kho, bhante, taṃ cakkhu, yena cakkhunā atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivaṭṭe paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya …pe…
sn35.83:2.1.eng: “Sir, suppose someone were to describe the Buddhas of the past who have become fully quenched, cut off proliferation, cut off the course, finished off the cycle, and passed beyond all suffering. Does the eye exist by which they could be described?
sn35.83:2.1.comm: Cited at Kv 1.6:95.3 with slight change. | This is the only doctrinal context where we find vaṭuma (“course”). The commentary explains it as the “course of craving”. However, in Buddhist Sanskrit we find the phrases chinnaṃ vartmaṃ na vartati (Mahāvastu 2.416) and chinnaṃ vartma na pravartate (Nidāna Saṁyukta 11.6), which recall the Pali phrase vaṭṭaṁ vattati (DN 15:22.6), where vaṭṭa occurs in the next word of the current passage. This suggests that the sense is, rather, the “course of transmigration”, as in the later Sanskrit phrase saṁsāravartmani.

sn35.83:2.2.pli: atthi nu kho, bhante, sā jivhā, yāya jivhāya atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivaṭṭe paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya …pe…
sn35.83:2.2.eng: Does the ear … nose … tongue … body exist …?

sn35.83:2.3.pli: atthi nu kho so, bhante, mano, yena manena atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivaṭṭe paññāpayamāno paññāpeyyā”ti?
sn35.83:2.3.eng: Does the mind exist by which they could be described?”

sn35.83:3.1.pli: “Natthi kho taṃ, phagguna, cakkhu, yena cakkhunā atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivaṭṭe paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya …pe…
sn35.83:3.1.eng: “Phagguna, suppose someone were to describe the Buddhas of the past who have become fully quenched, cut off proliferation, cut off the course, finished off the cycle, and passed beyond all suffering. The eye does not exist by which they could be described.

sn35.83:3.2.pli: natthi kho sā, phagguna, jivhā, yāya jivhāya atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivaṭṭe paññāpayamāno paññāpeyya …pe…
sn35.83:3.2.eng: The ear … nose … tongue … body does not exist …

sn35.83:3.3.pli: natthi kho so, phagguna, mano, yena manena atīte buddhe parinibbute chinnapapañce chinnavaṭume pariyādinnavaṭṭe sabbadukkhavītivaṭṭe paññāpayamāno paññāpeyyā”ti.
sn35.83:3.3.eng: The mind does not exist by which they could be described.”

sn35.84:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.84:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn35.84:2.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the world’.

sn35.84:2.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, lokoti vuccatī”ti?

sn35.84:2.3.pli: “Yaṃ kho, ānanda, palokadhammaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati ariyassa vinaye loko.
sn35.84:2.3.eng: “Ānanda, that which is liable to wear out is called the world in the training of the Noble One.
sn35.84:2.3.comm: Paloka (“wear out”) is a noun form of palujjati. See notes at SN 22.93:1.2 and SN 35.82:2.3.

sn35.84:2.4.eng: And what is liable to wear out?

sn35.84:2.5.pli: Cakkhu kho, ānanda, palokadhammaṃ, rūpā palokadhammā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ palokadhammaṃ, cakkhusamphasso palokadhammo, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā …pe… tampi palokadhammaṃ …pe…
sn35.84:2.5.eng: The eye is liable to wear out. Sights … eye consciousness … eye contact is liable to wear out. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also liable to wear out.

sn35.84:2.6.pli: jivhā palokadhammā, rasā palokadhammā, jivhāviññāṇaṃ palokadhammaṃ, jivhāsamphasso palokadhammo, yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā …pe… tampi palokadhammaṃ …pe…

sn35.84:2.7.pli: mano palokadhammo, dhammā palokadhammā, manoviññāṇaṃ palokadhammaṃ, manosamphasso palokadhammo, yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi palokadhammaṃ.
sn35.84:2.7.eng: The mind … ideas … mind consciousness … mind contact is liable to wear out. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also liable to wear out.

sn35.84:2.8.pli: Yaṃ kho, ānanda, palokadhammaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati ariyassa vinaye loko”ti.
sn35.84:2.8.eng: That which is liable to wear out is called the world in the training of the Noble One.”

sn35.85:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando …pe… bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.85:1.1.eng: And then Venerable Ānanda … said to the Buddha:

sn35.85:1.2.eng: “Sir, they say that ‘the world is empty’.

sn35.85:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, suñño lokoti vuccatī”ti?
sn35.85:1.3.eng: What does the saying ‘the world is empty’ refer to?”

sn35.85:1.4.pli: “Yasmā ca kho, ānanda, suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā tasmā suñño lokoti vuccati.
sn35.85:1.4.eng: “Ānanda, they say that ‘the world is empty’ because it’s empty of self or what belongs to self.
sn35.85:1.4.comm: “Emptiness” in early Buddhism is primarily a meditation approach for realizing not-self (SN 41.7:4.3 = MN 43:33.3 = MN 106:7.2; Snp 5.16:4.1). For a more expansive treatment, see MN 121.

sn35.85:1.5.pli: Kiñca, ānanda, suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā?
sn35.85:1.5.eng: And what is empty of self or what belongs to self?

sn35.85:1.6.pli: Cakkhu kho, ānanda, suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā.

sn35.85:1.7.pli: Rūpā suññā attena vā attaniyena vā, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā, cakkhusamphasso suñño attena vā attaniyena vā …pe…
sn35.85:1.7.eng: sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are empty of self or what belongs to self. …

sn35.85:1.8.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā.
sn35.85:1.8.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also empty of self or what belongs to self.

sn35.85:1.9.pli: Yasmā ca kho, ānanda, suññaṃ attena vā attaniyena vā, tasmā suñño lokoti vuccatī”ti.
sn35.85:1.9.eng: They say that ‘the world is empty’ because it’s empty of self or what belongs to self.”

sn35.86:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.86:1.1.eng: Seated to one side, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:

sn35.86:1.2.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn35.86:1.2.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn35.86:2.2.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.86:4.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.86:4.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.86:6.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.86:6.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.86:6.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.86:10.2.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.86:10.2.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.86:12.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.86:12.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.86:14.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.86:14.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.86:14.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.86:16.1.eng: “Is the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind …

sn35.86:18.3.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.86:18.3.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.86:20.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.86:20.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.86:22.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.86:22.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.86:22.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.86:24.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, ānanda, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati …pe… cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati …pe…
sn35.86:24.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact.

sn35.86:24.2.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.86:24.2.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body … mind … painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.86:24.3.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.86:24.3.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.86:24.4.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn35.86:24.4.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
